message_1: A factory produces detergent bottles with an average fill volume of 1.2 liters and a standard deviation of 0.05 liters. A random sample of 36 bottles is taken. Determine a 95% confidence interval for the mean fill volume of the detergent bottles produced by the factory.
message_2:
To determine a 95% confidence interval for the mean fill volume of the detergent bottles, we will use the formula for the confidence interval of a sample mean:

CI = x̄ ± Z * (σ / √n)

where CI is the confidence interval, x̄ is the sample mean, Z is the Z-score corresponding to the desired confidence level, σ is the population standard deviation, and n is the sample size.

In this case, we have:

x̄ = 1.2 liters (average fill volume)
σ = 0.05 liters (standard deviation)
n = 36 (sample size)

For a 95% confidence interval, the Z-score is 1.96 (you can find this value in a standard Z-score table).

Now we can plug these values into the formula:

CI = 1.2 ± 1.96 * (0.05 / √36)

CI = 1.2 ± 1.96 * (0.05 / 6)

CI = 1.2 ± 1.96 * 0.008333

CI = 1.2 ± 0.016333

The 95% confidence interval for the mean fill volume of the detergent bottles is (1.183667, 1.216333) liters. This means that we can be 95% confident that the true mean fill volume of the detergent bottles produced by the factory lies between 1.183667 liters and 1.216333 liters.
